ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body: ## Level 2 heading ### Level 3 heading #### Level 4 heading ##### Level 5 heading ###### Level 6 heading
> This is a block quote. This > paragraph has two lines. > > 1. This is a list inside a block quote. > 2. Second item.

blockquote.p: This is a block quote. This paragraph has two lines.

ol.li: This is a list inside a block quote.

p: Line block preserves spaces and new lines.
A horizontal line can be created using three or more * or -.
An example of footnote reference 1

p.code: [This content lives in the right margin]{.aside}

p.span: This content lives in the right margin

p: Verbatim code is text formatted using monospaced font intended as code. Verbatim code can be defined inline where `date()` looks like date().
Code can also be defined inside code blocks.
Source code, ie; code that is highlighted or executed in a quarto document is not covered here.
Code can be defined inline where `r Sys.Date()` renders 2025-02-25.
Code can be defined inside code blocks.
which shows the source code and output.
Here is another example of executed R code with input and output.

Properties and behaviour of code chunks can be controlled using chunk attributes. This is specified as comment sign of the language and pipe followed by key: value. So for example, in R: #| eval: false.
In this example, the R source code and results are hidden but the code is evaluated.

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body: ```{r} #| eval: true #| echo: false #| results: hide Sys.Date() ```

p: A code chunk can be given a code filename using the chunk attribute filename.
Enable line numbers using code-line-numbers: true.
An advanced example showing bash code generated from R.

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body: ```{r} #| attr-output: "filename='bash'" #| class-output: bash #| echo: false d <- "custom" cat(paste("mkdir​", d)) ```

p: Code chunk attributes are documented here.
Unordered lists are created using dashes.
Ordered lists are created using numbers.

Images can be inserted using plain markdown or HTML directly. Plain markdown can be embellished with custom quarto adjustments to modify aspects of the image. Clicking the image opens the image in a lightbox. This is made possible using the lightbox extension.
Using regular markdown.
The dimensions are based on image and/or fill up the entire available space. You can control the dimension as shown below.
This image above is now 30% of it’s original width.
More figure options and layouts are described here. Cross referencing described here.
Quarto chunks can be used to control image display size using the argument out.width.
This image below is displayed at a size of 300 pixels.
This image below is displayed at a size of 75 pixels and a caption added.

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body: ```{r} #| out-width: 75px #| fig-cap: This is a caption knitr::include_graphics("quarto.webp") ```

p: For more information on figures, see here. For plots generated through R, see section further below.
Some examples of rendering equations.
Call-Out blocks are explained here.
For simple cases, tables can be manually created in markdown.
Simple table using kable from R package knitr. This is the default output for quarto.

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body: Sepal.Length Sepal.Width Petal.Length Petal.Width Species 1 5.1 3.5 1.4 0.2 setosa 2 4.9 3.0 1.4 0.2 setosa 3 4.7 3.2 1.3 0.2 setosa 4 4.6 3.1 1.5 0.2 setosa 5 5.0 3.6 1.4 0.2 setosa 6 5.4 3.9 1.7 0.4 setosa

```{r} #| column: body-outset #| label: tbl-dual-table #| tbl-cap: "Example" #| tbl-subcap: #| - "Cars" #| - "Pressure" #| layout-ncol: 2
kable(head(cars)) kable(head(pressure)) ```

p: Images and tables can be automatically numbered by using label attribute. Image label must start with fig- and tables with tbl-. Tables and images can also be cross-referenced when using the label attribute. For example, the table above can be referenced like @tbl-dual-table which renders as Table 1.

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body:
```{r} #| fig-caption: This table is in the margin. #| column: margin
head(cars) ```

div.data-fig-caption: This table is in the margin.

p: Tables using the gt package. A structured approach to creating tables using grammar of tables with extensive customization options.

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body:
library(gt)
iris %>% group_by(Species) %>% slice(1:4) %>% gt() %>% cols_label( Sepal.Length = "Sepal Length", Sepal.Width = "Sepal Width", Petal.Length = "Petal Length", Petal.Width = "Petal Width" ) %>% tab_source_note( source_note = md("Source: Iris data. Anderson, 1936; Fisher, 1936)") )

p: Interactive table using R package DT. DT tables do not work in confluence.
Advanced interactive tables with reactable. reactables do not work in confluence.

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body:
library(reactable)
reactable(iris[sample(1:150, 10), ], columns = list( Sepal.Length = colDef(name = "Sepal Length"), Sepal.Width = colDef(name = "Sepal Width"), Petal.Width = colDef(name = "Petal Width"), Petal.Width = colDef(name = "Petal Width") ), striped = TRUE, highlight = TRUE, filterable = TRUE )

p: Divs can be nested like this:
Both spans and divs support attributes in this specific order: identifiers, classes, and then key-value attributes.
Conditional content is documented here.
Organisation of content into columns within the body container.
This is an example of nested columns.
Extending content outside the body container.

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body:
::: {.panel-tabset} #### Sub topic 1
This is some material for topic 1.
#### Sub topic 2
This is some material for topic 2.
:::

div.p: This is some material for topic 1.
This is some material for topic 2.

p: More layout settings are described here and here.

ul.li: Plots using base R are widely used and may be good enough for most situations.
But they lack a consistent coding framework.

ac:image.ac:caption: Figure 2: Static plot using base plot.

p: This does not work.

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body:
```{r} #| eval: false #| column: screen-inset-shaded #| layout-nrow: 1 #| fig-cap: #| - "Scatterplot of speed vs distance" #| - "Pairwise scatterplot of all variables" #| - "Scatterplot of temperature vs pressure"
plot(cars) plot(iris) plot(pressure) ```

p: R package ggplot2 is one of the most versatile and complete plotting solutions.

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body:
library(ggplot2)
iris %>% ggplot(aes(x=Sepal.Length,y=Sepal.Width,col=Species))+ geom_point(size=2)+ labs(x="Sepal Length",y="Sepal Width")

p: Quarto supports ObservableJS for interactive visualisations in the browser.
Pass data from R to OJS

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body: irism <- iris colnames(irism) <- gsub("[.]","_",tolower(colnames(irism))) ojs_define(ojsd = irism)

p: Display as a table
Define inputs

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body: viewof x = Inputs.select(Object.keys(ojsdata[0]), {value: "sepal_length", multiple: false, label: "X axis"})
viewof y = Inputs.select(Object.keys(ojsdata[0]), {value: "sepal_width", multiple: false, label: "Y axis"})

p: Display plot
ObservableJS in quarto documentation.

CSF is an XML markup language used by Atlassian Confluence to represent content. Quarto supports CSF for creating Confluence documents. It is similar to HTML in many ways but with confluence specific tags.
Here is an example of a task list.

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body: ```{=confluence} 1 complete Wake Up 2 incomplete Brush Teeth 3 incomplete Eat Breakfast ```

p: Here are examples of an emojis.
A decision list.

ac:structured-macro.ac:plain-text-body:
```{=confluence} ad7b0a98-1e3e-4863-8f23-ff44dbd7dfa1 c25ea574-62d6-4770-bf11-5a27f3309d56 DECIDED Use Quarto
  • Use Quarto
 ```

p: Here is a page tree.
A quarto document can be published to a confluence page using the quarto publish command. The command requires a configuration file _publish.yml that specifies the confluence server.

li.p: That reference refers to this footnote.↩︎
